instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00687: What is 820-00687? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1534: What is A1534? A1534 is a model number for a 12 inch size Macbook  from years 2015, 2016 with EMC 2746, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00045, 820-00244..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H? This is the input from the USB-C charger or the battery that is the input voltage for the chip responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H. It can be missing when capacitors on this line are shorted to ground, or when the diode in front of it leading to the chip that creates PP3V3_G3H is blown. .
definitions.PP3V3R3V0_AON: What is PP3V3R3V0_AON? PP3V3R3V0_AON is the first power rail you need to get a USB-C charger to go from 5v to 20v on an A1534 Macbook with an 820-00045 board..
definitions.PP5V_G3H: What is PP5V_G3H? PP5V_G3H is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a G3H mechanical off state.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't seem to turn on
threads.message:
I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> which came in with a broken screen and a flat battery. The screen assembly was replaced and it doesn't seem to have any signs of life apart from the led on the board.

I've checked the basics but I'm at a loss. It was with another company first but they apparently "hadn't touched it" (Although the trackpad connector flap had gone missing)

8.63v <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
14.67v <SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL>
8.63v <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>
14.69v <SIGNAL>PPVBUS_LIO</SIGNAL>
14.69v <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>
3.29v <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
3.29v <SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL>
4.96v <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3H</SIGNAL>

Any ideas where to start from here?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't seem to turn on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5.0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.32v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 3.3v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> is boosting to 3.37v every 4 seconds

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't seem to turn on
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.29v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't seem to turn on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_SUS_PCH</SIGNAL> = 1.001v
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU_PH1</SIGNAL> & PH2 0.00v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> = 3.35v pulses every 4 seconds

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't seem to turn on
threads.message:
Check if <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> pulses too.
Then check if all voltages controlled by these signals also pulse.
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is pulsing?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't seem to turn on
threads.message: Okay, I’ll check that tomorrow. 11 hours until work as there’s a time difference unfortunately

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't seem to turn on
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> are also pulsing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't seem to turn on
threads.message: Followed <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> into <CHIP>U8170</CHIP>, <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> going into <CHIP>U8170</CHIP> is also pulsing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't seem to turn on
threads.message: Check if ALL S3 and S0 voltages try to appear.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't seem to turn on
threads.message: So far nothing on S0

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't seem to turn on
threads.message: My bad.. was on the wrong component.. <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> is pulsing.. checking the rest

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't seem to turn on
threads.message:
So I get pulsing on all of these:  <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>

Anything I've missed?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't seem to turn on
threads.message:
You should have more S0 voltages.
Not always marked as S0, but check every secondary supply enabled by <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>, or a derivate of it.
Can you see any pulse on CPU VCORE?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't seem to turn on
threads.message: Theres no pulse on VCORE

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't seem to turn on
threads.message: On <CHIP>U8230</CHIP> I had a constant 5v out for <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> for a minute until I moved the board to recheck the first place that I checked <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>. I'm now back to pulsing though :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't seem to turn on
threads.message: Do you note any sign of liquid on the LCD connector?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't seem to turn on
threads.message:
<CHIP>U8220</CHIP> - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> out is 3.3v constant
<CHIP>U8230</CHIP> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> is pulsing
<CHIP>U8200</CHIP> - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> is pulsing
<CHIP>U8210</CHIP> - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is pulsing
<CHIP>U8250</CHIP> - <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> is pulsing
<CHIP>U8240</CHIP> - <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S0SW</SIGNAL> is pulsing
<CHIP>U8270</CHIP> - <SIGNAL>PP1V_S3</SIGNAL> / sus is 1v constant
<CHIP>U8206</CHIP> - <SIGNAL>PP1V_S0SW</SIGNAL> 1v constant

Are these what you mean?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't seem to turn on
threads.message: There's nothing on there under a microscope. The trackpad looks like it may have seen a touch of liquid at one edge but nothing major

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't seem to turn on
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> is pulsing also

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't seem to turn on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is constant 
<SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is pulsing
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is pulsing
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is constant 3.3v

So maybe <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> issue?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't seem to turn on
threads.message:
Bad screen can means dropped machine.
This could caused broken solder/traces; possibly nightmare...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't seem to turn on
threads.message: Could be. I was told that the boyfriend hit the screen. I still don't understand what it is telling me by pulsing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't seem to turn on
threads.message:
Pulsing voltage means respective power supplies receive enable and generate voltage.
For some reason power sequence is not completed.
SMC can detect a fault, or maybe PCH doesn't work as should be.
Try to start in SMC bypass mode, just in case...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't seem to turn on
threads.message: SMC bypass on these... is that with the board back in and battery connected or without the battery?  Hold power button for 10 seconds and keep holding for another 10 seconds while plugging in the power lead right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't seem to turn on
threads.message:
Something like that.
Good enough to test...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't seem to turn on
threads.message: Nothing from this board when I try to bypass SMC

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't seem to turn on
threads.message: Do I need the battery connected for SMC bypass or does it not matter on these?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't seem to turn on
threads.message: Did you try to start in SMC bypass mode without battery connected?
